content.1: Boast not thyself of to morrow; for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth.
content.2: Let another man praise thee, and not thine own mouth; a stranger, and not thine own lips.
content.7: The full soul loatheth an honeycomb; but to the hungry soul every bitter thing is sweet.
content.8: As a bird that wandereth from her nest, so
content.9: Ointment and perfume rejoice the heart: so
content.10: Thine own friend, and thy father’s friend, forsake not; neither go into thy brother’s house in the day of thy calamity:
content.11: My son, be wise, and make my heart glad, that I may answer him that reproacheth me.
content.13: Take his garment that is surety for a stranger, and take a pledge of him for a strange woman.
content.14: He that blesseth his friend with a loud voice, rising early in the morning, it shall be counted a curse to him.
content.15: A continual dropping in a very rainy day and a contentious woman are alike.
content.16: Whosoever hideth her hideth the wind, and the ointment of his right hand,
content.17: Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.
content.18: Whoso keepeth the fig tree shall eat the fruit thereof: so he that waiteth on his master shall be honoured.
content.20: Hell and destruction are never full; so the eyes of man are never satisfied.
content.22: Though thou shouldest bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle,
content.23: Be thou diligent to know the state of thy flocks,
content.25: The hay appeareth, and the tender grass sheweth itself, and herbs of the mountains are gathered.
